etymologies: late 19th century; earliest use found in The New Sydenham Society's Lexicon of Medicine and the Allied Sciences. From phellandr- (in scientific Latin Phellandrium, former genus name (Linnaeus Systema Naturae) of a water dropwort (P. aquaticum; now called Oenanthe aquatica), from the seeds of which one of the compounds was first isolated; from classical Latin phellandrion (in Pliny), of uncertain origin; perhaps from Greek) + -ene, after Italian fellantrene

definitions: Each of two isomeric cyclic terpenes having the formula C₁₀ H₁₆ (more fully "α-phellandrene" and "β-phellandrene"), which are fragrant liquids found in the essential oils of many plants and used in perfumery.
